pullrequest.title: data_source for SlicePlot, adding a cut_region selector

content.raw: I tried to do this using cython's wrapper for `std::map`, but ran into issues.  For one thing, trying to link against the STL caused clang to barf on my mac.  It seems that python's dictionary is pretty fast, and generating slices of cut regions seems pretty zippy in my tests, so I'm pretty happy with this solution.
content.html: I tried to do this using cython's wrapper for std::map, but ran into issues. For one thing, trying to link against the STL caused clang to barf on my mac. It seems that python's dictionary is pretty fast, and generating slices of cut regions seems pretty zippy in my tests, so I'm pretty happy with this solution.

pullrequest.title: data_source for SlicePlot, adding a cut_region selector

content.raw:
I'm confused by base_object and data_source as they seem to duplicate functionality. It may not be api compatible, but you could have YTCutRegion take only the conditional parameter. Then define the CutRegion selector to only apply the position check, rather than having a base selector. Then use compose to combine the data_source selector and the cut_region selector.

Does that make sense?
content.html:
I'm confused by base_object and data_source as they seem to duplicate functionality. It may not be api compatible, but you could have YTCutRegion take only the conditional parameter. Then define the CutRegion selector to only apply the position check, rather than having a base selector. Then use compose to combine the data_source selector and the cut_region selector.

Does that make sense?

pullrequest.title: data_source for SlicePlot, adding a cut_region selector

content.raw: I think that would work, but can we put it off for a future PR?  I worry about breaking or adding overhead to projections of cut regions.
content.html: I think that would work, but can we put it off for a future PR? I worry about breaking or adding overhead to projections of cut regions.

pullrequest.title: data_source for SlicePlot, adding a cut_region selector

content.raw: Should the data_source retain its field_parameters so you can use them in derived fields? You can definitely still use the field parameters dictionary argument, but the when you specify a data_source for a projection plot, it allows you to use the field parameters.
content.html: Should the data_source retain its field_parameters so you can use them in derived fields? You can definitely still use the field parameters dictionary argument, but the when you specify a data_source for a projection plot, it allows you to use the field parameters.

content.raw: `base_object`. If it's an API objection I understand, but a user shouldn't be able to provide both `base_object` and `data_source`.
content.html: base_object. If it's an API objection I understand, but a user shouldn't be able to provide both base_object and data_source.

pullrequest.title: data_source for SlicePlot, adding a cut_region selector

content.raw: Then `data_source` should be removed, no?  I don't think it's possible to create a cut region without a `base_object`.
content.html: Then data_source should be removed, no? I don't think it's possible to create a cut region without a base_object.

pullrequest.title: data_source for SlicePlot, adding a cut_region selector

content.raw: I would imagine a cut region without `data_source` (assuming `base_object` no longer exists) would cut against `ds.all_data()`. Then the api for this data object would behave like every other data object.
content.html: I would imagine a cut region without data_source (assuming base_object no longer exists) would cut against ds.all_data(). Then the api for this data object would behave like every other data object.

pullrequest.title: data_source for SlicePlot, adding a cut_region selector

content.raw:
So the way cut regions normally get created is via a `.cut_region` method attached to a data source.  Really, `base_object` is mostly an internal API that is used by the various `cut_region` functions attached to the data sources.

I think I could get rid of the internal use of `base_object`, then issue an error if someone uses `YTCutRegion` directly and supplies both `data_source` and `base_object`.  I think it makes sense to use `data_source` here unconditionally to keep things uniform with the other data objects.

I'll try to look at this later today.  Thanks for clarifying things for me!
content.html:
So the way cut regions normally get created is via a .cut_region method attached to a data source. Really, base_object is mostly an internal API that is used by the various cut_region functions attached to the data sources.

I think I could get rid of the internal use of base_object, then issue an error if someone uses YTCutRegion directly and supplies both data_source and base_object. I think it makes sense to use data_source here unconditionally to keep things uniform with the other data objects.

I'll try to look at this later today. Thanks for clarifying things for me!

pullrequest.title: data_source for SlicePlot, adding a cut_region selector

description:
This uses the new selector composition machinery to create a `data_source` keyword argument for `SlicePlot`.

Example: http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/ngoldbaum/7d0a0b244ba8cd10fd43

Update: I've also implemented a cut_region selector and added some documentation. I'd really appreciate it if @drudd could look this over.
